title: After loss to Warren, Republican John Deaton announces another run for Senate
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: John Deaton, after losing to Elizabeth Warren, announces candidacy for Sen. Ed Markey's seat in Massachusetts.
Deaton criticizes Markey as a career politician, highlighting his own Marine veteran background and commitment to Massachusetts families.
Deaton is the first Republican candidate to enter the 2026 Senate race, emphasizing youth and an independent voice.

title: What will the Red Sox target this offseason? Craig Breslow maps out Boston’s priorities.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox Chief Baseball Officer Craig Breslow seeks a new top pitcher to pair with ace Garrett Crochet.
Boston considers trades for elite pitchers like Joe Ryan, Freddy Peralta, or MacKenzie Gore.
Adding power hitters like Kyle Schwarber or Pete Alonso is a priority to boost the Red Sox lineup.

title: Zdeno Chara’s 10 most memorable moments with the Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Zdeno Chara inducted into Hockey Hall of Fame, celebrated for his defensive prowess and leadership with the Bruins.
Chara served as Boston Bruins captain for 14 seasons and led the team to a Stanley Cup victory in 2011.
Chara set the record for hardest shot in NHL history at 108.8 mph during the 2012 All-Star Game.

title: Bill Belichick reflects on ‘learning curve’ during first season coaching college football
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Bill Belichick reflects on challenges during his first college coaching season with North Carolina, currently 4-5 in ACC.
UNC Tar Heels improved after early struggles, achieving back-to-back wins; aiming to reach a .500 season record.
Belichick emphasizes learning from initial misjudgments and adjusting player roles for better team performance.

title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots have 15 players on the injury report with Austin Hooper missing practice due to a concussion.
Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson, who missed Sunday's game, were limited participants in Monday's practice.
Team faces a short week as they prepare for a Thursday game against the Jets after a win over the Buccaneers.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, 44, from Georgia, accused of stealing millions by filing false claims to Massachusetts' unclaimed property division.
Stayman allegedly forged documents to claim $1.1 million, with attempts to claim an additional $2.2 million thwarted by authorities.
Stayman held on $2 million bail; awaits sentencing for separate Alabama federal fraud case in December, with co-defendant arraigned soon.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson, unsure of end-game strategy, looked to the sideline during a key touchdown run against Tampa Bay.
Henderson's late-game touchdown performance marked his first game with over 100 yards and multiple scores as a rookie.
With Rhamondre Stevenson injured, Henderson has stepped up, showcasing an increased role in the Patriots' offense.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei returned to the Bruins lineup against Toronto after being a healthy scratch for five consecutive games.
Lohrei contributed significantly in the Bruins' 5-3 win over the Maple Leafs with two assists and strong defensive play.
Head coach Marco Sturm's lineup changes, including Lohrei's benching, are fostering competition and performance improvement among Bruins players.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Petitioners seeking to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters about petition content in Massachusetts.
The Coalition for a Healthy Massachusetts aims to make possessing over an ounce of marijuana illegal through a ballot question.
State and local officials have received complaints of misrepresentation; the petitioners deny using deceitful tactics.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, slightly down from $10.26 billion in 2024.
All top 15 highest-paid state employees are from UMass, with Frank Martin leading at $1,955,216 annually.
UMass accounted for $1.55 billion in payroll, followed by the MBTA with $799.68 million and Trial Court with $574.67 million.
